ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures
N/A
We met everyday over Zoom for our seminar, but there were a couple of days throughout the semester where we had class asynchronously and watched a movie or video on our own that day.
Live virtual discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the fundamentals of the Italian language.
I learned an incredible amount of Italian vocabulary as well as more about the Italian culture.
I learned quite a bit of basic Italian. I'm able to speak and write in Italian much more than I would've expected after having only taken Italian for one semester.
A comprehensive understanding of basic Italian.

The basics of the Italian language! We learned lots of vocabulary, verb conjugations, and the fundamental grammatical rules. Every unit, we'd also learn a little bit about Italian culture/history as well.
I acquired a great foundation in the basics of the Italian language, including grammar and vocabulary, as well as a bit of Italian cultural knowledge.
Professor Barchiesi did a great job of teaching us the beginning skills and tools for learning Italian.
Italian vocabulary and grammar, practice speaking and writing Italian.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I can't find any weaknesses for this course!
I think the course was taught very well and helped to greatly facilitate student learning by going over the workbook activities in class.

I thought the course moved at a good pace. I learned a lot but it wasn't overwhelming. Costanza was great and made sure to be engaging and encourage everyone to participate. Also, the course was fun and the classes felt relaxed.

Strengths: fun and laidback environment, predictable/consistent nature of assignments, great textbook with lots of study resources and practice, reasonable workload for a foreign language course, great instructor
Weaknesses: many of the in-class activities are heavily based on reviewing HW, could've had more opportunities to practice speaking and writing

Costanza Barchiesi is an absolutely wonderful instructor. Having class Monday through Friday was a big commitment, but it was always enjoyable because Costanza made learning the material fun and low-stress. The class is taught almost entirely in Italian which was really helpful for learning the language. I wouldn't say there were any weaknesses to this class. Overall, it was a great course and I learned a lot.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that I was still very engaged with the course even in the online format since it was a daily course. The daily homework helped to make things feel more "normal" since we were able to complete it online.
The live virtual classes via Zoom were pretty successful and everyone participated in class.
It's just very isolating.

The breakout rooms were fun and helpful for practice! I would've personally enjoyed having more of them to improve my speaking and listening skills. Despite the virtual format, I feel like I was still able to learn a lot and participate in class.

This course did a great job adapting to virtual learning. The Zoom meetings ran smoothly and the format where we raised our hands to talk eliminated any awkward pauses or people talking over each other. The few asynchronous meetings were fun too, and were a nice occasional break to the monotony of the semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student! It is a great introduction to Italian.
I would highly recommend this course to another student! I really loved it and Costanza made it really enjoyable to learn Italian.

Yes. Costanza is so nice. Although the class meets everyday, which takes up time, the daily homework takes less than half an hour to do and is predictable. This course is fun and engaging and you learn a lot in just one semester. If you participate in class and study for the tests it's not difficult to get a good grade.
Absolutely, Costanza is a great professor and Italian is a great language.
Absolutely, Costanza is an awesome instructor who made Italian really fun and easy to learn.

Yes! It's probably one of the more laidback foreign language credits, but you still end up learning a ton about the Italian language and rich culture. It's pretty fast-paced and it could be difficult if you've never learned a Romance language before (the whole class is pretty much taught in Italian), but if you keep up with the work every day, you'll do fine. Costanza is such an amazing instructor, and she's here to help you succeed! She's incredibly kind and friendly, and it's such a joy to come to class every day.
Yes! Any student wanting to learn a fun and beautiful language in a low-stress environment should definitely take this course!
Yes! This was such a fun course and now I plan on taking Italian all throughout college!
I would recommend this course to another student because Italian  is a beautiful language that was taught in this course in a wen organized way.
Yes
